values:
I have decided to switch my blog to blogger, for several reasons - none of which are interesting enough to post about :) Include it in the things that are changing around here!

So change your links to smallfryeh.blogspot.com, and enjoy! Perhaps I'll be better about posting more regularly.

Most of you know, but for those who don't, I find myself in the midst of yet another huge transition period in my life.  Hopefully this is the last HUGE transition period for a long time - I'm ready to be settled.  Transition times for me become times when I attempt to become more aware of who I am and who God has created me to be, which often means I'm reading every book I can get my hand on.  Lately I have found myself making a list in my head of books that I want to read, but I haven't kept track of them anywhere and I end up forgetting them.  So, here's my list (please add those books you think I should add to this list!)

Twentysomething, by Margaret Feinberg
The Organic God, by Margert Feinberg,
What the Heck Am I Going to Do With My Life? by Margaret Feinberg
Five Star Living on a Two Star Budget, by Margaret Feinberg
The Shack, by William Young
Velvet Elvis, by Rob Bell
They Like Jesus but not the Church, by Dan Kimball
Adventures in Missing the Point, by Brian McLaren and Tony Campolo
The Ragamuffin Gospel, by Brennan Manning
Everything is Illuminated, by Jonathan Safran Foer
Gilead, by Marilynne Robinson
Water for Elephants, by Sara Gruen
Mountains Beyond Mountains, by Tracy Kidder
A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, by Dave Eggers
Jesus Land, by Julia Scheeres
Leaving Church, by Barbara Brown Taylor
The Serenity Prayer: Faith and Politics in Times of Peace and War, by Elisabeth Sifton
Faith and Feminism: A Holy Alliance, by Helen LaKelly Hunt
America's Women, by Gail Collins
Rediscovering Friendship, by Elisabeth Moltmann-Wendel
The Management Methods of Jesus, by Bob Briner

Currently reading:
Give it up! My Year of Learning to Live with Less, by Mary Carlomagno
Eat, Pray, Love, by Elizabeth Gilbert
The Outcast, by Sadie Jones

Someone anonymously asked "What is your biggest regret and your biggest fear?"  First - whoever Anonymous is ... I almost don't want to answer this because I'm not sure who asked it...you really ought to sign up for livejournal if you want to dialogue with me :)

My biggest regret ... I honestly don't know that I have a biggest regret (at least not one that I'm comfortable sharing with the entire livejournal and internet world).  So - anonymous ... if you really want to know the answer to that question, shoot me an email and let me know who you are :)  In all seriousness, my philosophy on regrets is that there's no point having regrets.  We all make a thousand decisions in our lifetimes, and if we focus on how we made the wrong decision, our lives become too much about the past and not enough about the present.  I think every decision I've made, I've made for a good reason at the time, and God has worked through each decision to show me something new about me and something new about who God is and how God works.

My biggest fear ... is living a life that is not worth living.  Leaving this earth and not having an affect on people's lives.  Living a life worth forgetting.  I want to live my life in such a way that I make an impact on people - that people see God through me.  My biggest fear is that I don't do that every day of my life.

So a while ago (back on March 31) I started the "question game"...ask me a question and I'll answer. I was really bad about answering - for those of you who know me well, you know the months of April and May have been a complete whirlwind (some would call it a disaster, but I consider it a learning experience). So here I am ... catching up on answering the questions.  I'll do a separate entry for each question ... so get ready for some reading pleasure!

falling_star24
asked: "Ok, what were you like as a little kid?"

I really really love this question, but I'm not sure how to answer it.  I have asked my mom to see what her thoughts are, but here's what I remember.  I was fun.  I don't remember causing much trouble - I have always been very tenderhearted and never wanted to hurt anyone's feelings.  So when I thought about causing trouble, I immediately thought how badly it would hurt my mom (or other family) and decided against it.  Yeah ... I've always been the goody-two-shoes that I am now :)  Most of my memories from my childhood are from either church or daycare, and most have my aunts in them.  My mom is one of 9 kids - 8 still living (5 girls and 3 boys).  When I grew up, three of my aunts plus my mom all lived in Griffin and mom was the only one with kids.  So we had a whole bunch of attention and a whole lot of love!  My sisters are in just about every memory I have.  I am the oldest of three, April is 4 years younger than me and Michelle is 7 1/2 years younger than me, so we were spaced pretty good.  Sure, we fought - but we were always very loyal to one another to the outside world.  I LOVED church.  I was there a lot.  We were there every Sunday for Sunday School and Worship, and children's choir was one of my favorite activities - VBS was one of my favorite times of year.  My best friend Melissa and I used to try to out-sing each other ... someone even has tapes of it!

My mom's thoughts:
"Well, you were happy most of the time. Laughed alot.  Smiled alot.  Liked to have your hair pretty, didn't like your clothes or hands to be dirty.  Very loving, liked hugs.  Liked to be around mommy or grandma.  Liked to read and listen to music.  Just like you are now."

I guess some people never change :)

I got the awesome new palm centro last weekend.  I'm still getting used to it, but it's good to have at least limited internet access at home again. Here I am on the road (not driving) and still posting! Technology is amazing. Kate, I promise a real post very soon!

1. Whats harder to live without, chocolate or alcohol?  I could definitely live without alcohol - although I do love me a glass of good wine.  But chocolate chip cookies ... I think it would be a very sad world without chocolate chip cookies.
  2. Does the colour yellow remind you of anything? Sunshine ... on my shoulders :)
  3. Who most annoyed you last week? Hmm ... I don't think I should write that for all the world to see...
  4. Do you have a cutesy romantic nickname for your partner (or previous partners)? Nope
  5. What is your favourite Stephen King movie? I thought that I had only seen one Stephen King movie - the mini-series The Stand, but when I looked up a list of his stuff, I saw that The Green Mile was one of his.  So, that would be my favorite of the two I've seen.  I'm not a huge Stephen King fan, if you can't tell :)

Josh and I are trying to read through the Bible in a year.  We have gotten behind, and are now trying to catch up (separately).  Last night, I was reading Exodus, and finishing up the story of the plagues.  As I read it, I could identify with Pharaoh.  Strange identification huh?  Everytime a plague hit, Pharaoh gave in to Moses (and so therefore gave in to God).  But when the plague was over, Pharaoh went back to his old ways and forgot the awesomeness of God's power.  I thought that was a lot like most of my life has been.  When bad times hit, or during times of transition, I immediately turn to God - I say that I'm surrendering to His will - that I'm trying to listen to what God's calling me to.  Then, when I get in the swing of things and the time of transition is over, or my sadness and confusion has left, I neglect my personal relationship with God (for whatever reason) and try to rationalize that I'm nurturing my personal relationship with God in other ways - that Bible reading and prayer isn't really that important for me.  Until another time of sadness, confusion, or transition hits, and the cycle starts all over.  I know I'm only human and I will always fall short, but this realization is quite a big one for me.  To be able to compare myself to Pharaoh in this story is quite remarkable - in the not positive sense of the word.  So, this time, I'd like for me to keep up with the intentional tending of my personal relationship with God.  Perhaps from time to time I'll share those reflections on this blog.  Sometimes it helps to think it all out and put it out there for other thoughts, if any.

I am officially an employee again.  WOOHOO!  After a 2 1/2 month hiatus from working, I was ready to go back.  It's especially great that my going back to work consists of working at a great place with great people, doing the one thing I am most passionate about - church.  There are going to be tons of opportunities for me to plug in at Redeemer, and I am way excited about it.  It's gonna be a busy job, that's for sure, but busy in a very good way.  My boss isn't there this week or next, so I'm spending my first two weeks getting acclimated to the existing ministries, staff members, and goings on.  I spent my first day touring the building (2 hours or so) and learning some basics about the organizational structure of the congregation.  Tomorrow's schedule consists of a staff meeting and trying to connect with some of the staff members to learn what they do.  It's always interesting going into a new church as a staff member - it can be both a rewarding and not-so-rewarding experience.  Luckily, this one seems like it's going to be very positive.  The people are all great - very welcoming, and very excited to add me to their staff.

I'm headed out to this cute little Cuban restaurant tonight with two of my girlfriends that I went to AFFIRM with ... it's amazing that the people I consider some of my bestest friends are all people who I only spent a week or so with growing up - it's a wonderful testament to the power of God's community.  Anyway - I'm excited for tacos and margaritas with two of my besties :)

In other news - WTF is up with this weather?????  I have my frickin' heat on (well, it's not blowing at the moment, but that's because I refuse to set the thermostat up past 65).  I didn't bring my coat with me, or many winter clothes for that matter, because I thought it would be warm from here on out.  BOO HISS - come back spring time!!

I start my new job tomorrow - YAY!!

No other news to report.  Know someone who has multiple RENT tickets for sale for this weekend (in Atlanta) if anyone is interested.  They're super good seats...I think he'll sell them for $50 each (and he may even throw in the parking pass too!)  Let me know if you're interested.

My last post seemed kinda sad ... I guess I was a little depressed when I wrote it :)  Things are better since then, but I always knew they would be ;-)  I met most of my neighbors on Monday night and this is gonna end up to be a great place for me to live.  There are 10 apartments in our building, and 3 are open, so there are 7 of us plus one boyfriend and plus an old tenant who likes to come around pretty often.  It seems to be a great community - a lot of them hang out together pretty frequently and they've been quick to let me know if I ever need anything to not hesitate to ask.  At least 3 others have multiple cats and have assured me they would be more than happy to take care of the Sim-man if I ever need to go anywhere.  Good to know, since I was a little worried about the week of Affirm :)  I had dinner with a new friend (from Vocare) last night, and it was good to have someone to hang out with for a little bit, and then I ran into another Vocare friend today at Whole Foods.  It's beginning to really feel like home, which I'm super glad about.

I made a new quilt this week and it is way super cool .. I can't wait until it gets quilted and I can put it on my bed :)  Tomorrow I'm going to spend the whole day reading and then Friday I'm gonna head to the mountains for the weekend to pick up a few more things and spend a day or so with Josh before I start work on Monday.  I'm ready for Spring to be past and Summer to be here - the pollen is mega-crazy around here.  I cleaned my apartment today and the Swiffer was yellow when I got done.  GROSS!  My whole head feels it too, and the Zyrtec D doesn't seem to be helping any.

Took my car to Saturn today because the stupid thing keeps not wanting to start at random times.  I've had it looked at several times because of the same problem, and each time they've sworn that it's been fixed (but obviously not).  So you can imagine how frustrated I was to have to take it AGAIN.  It wasn't so bad this time because I only had to drive 20 minutes (11 miles) instead of 2 + hours (128 miles).  Again, they couldn't find anything wrong with it, but said the negative battery cable was a little loose and my fusebox was loose, so they tightened both, didn't charge me a penny, and sent me on my way.  Whaddya know - it started better today than it has in about a year.  It's the little blessings in life that make me happiest :)

That's all for now - time for the evening news :)

My username is _____ because ____

Smallfryeh because growing up I was always the shortest and littlest, and my friends thought it clever to call me "Small fry" and "Half pint".  When I tried to get "Smallfry" as an AIM name, it was taken - so I added a silent "eh" to it and it's been that way every since :)

My name is _____ because ______.

Crystal Marie Oxner Klein (Shortened to Crystal Klein if you know me well) because my Mom named me Crystal Marie (not sure where the names came from), my real dad's name is Oxner and I kept it because all my church folk knew me as Crystal Oxner, and Klein because I married into it and wanted a last name other than the one that identified me with my dad.

My journal is titled ____ because ____.

Home of the NuttyPeach because my super cool Ohio BL girls named me the NuttyPeach when I moved from Ohio (the buckeye state - 'nutty') back to Georgia (the peach state - 'peach')

My friends page is called ____ because ____.

I don't think my friends page has a title other than Friends...that's just because i haven't figured out how to change it.

My default userpic is ____ because ____
The one you see on this post.  I chose it as my default pic because it's me and Joshie and it's a good picture of the two of us.

I'm mostly all the way moved in to my cute new apartment in Atlanta.  It's really amazing what you can fit in 650 sq ft - it seems like I brought tons of stuff with me, but remarkably there's all kinds of room left :)  I left my books, dvds, and cds, among some other things, so Josh is planning on bringing them to me on Saturday.  I'm hoping to pull out all my sewing stuff next week and christen the place with strings and fabric scraps :)
Simba is a little nervous, but I think he'll be okay.  He's never been an only cat before, so I'm a little worried about him, but my mom says cats are adaptable and he'll be fine.  Tigger is here for the weekend, so they're exploring the new place together.

So, on top of the great location, awesome floorplan, and what seem to be pretty good neighbors, I am picking up someone else's wireless internet (it works for internet, but I can't get my entourage to download messages, and I haven't tried to download anything but webpages yet), and I splurged on a $20 rabbit-ear antenna today and I get all the major network channels ... ABC, NBC, CBS, Fox, and the CW comes in somewhat - so I am all set to watch all my shows.  That means I CAN WATCH AMERICAN IDOL :)  I missed last night because I was on my way back to Blairsville, but I'm sure the recap will give me all the info I need.

I'm flat exhausted, so I'm not gonna read through entries - but I'll catch up soon, promise!  For now, I'm off to enjoy my new place and rest a little before I have to finish putting clothes away tomorrow.  <3

I have internet at my apartment thanks to someone ... so THANKS SOMEONE!  the real test will be whether or not i can watch abc shows online with this internet.  If i can, and if i can figure out who someone is, they are getting brownies :)

in response to
randomepiphany
:

I have always, since I was a little girl, wanted to live in Atlanta.  I grew up in Griffin, GA, which is about an hour south of the city, and as a teenager had many friends who lived closer to Atlanta than I did.  I loved to visit them because there was so much to do!  When I was a senior in high school, we moved to Blairsville (the mountains of GA) and I never thought I'd come back to this area.  I went away to college (Va my first year, then Indiana my last three) then law school in Ohio - all the while hoping to get back to Georgia.  I almost went to law school in Atlanta, but decided to go to Ohio to be closer to my husband's family and grandma who was in her 90's.  My last year of law school I looked for jobs all over the country, focusing mostly on cities.  There's so much social justice work happening in the cities, and that's what I really longed to be a part of.  I thought I could use my background in theology with my law degree to do advocacy work for people living in poverty or provide legal services for people living in poverty.  Unfortunately I was unable to find any such position and ended up taking a position in Blairsville with a solo practitioner who was looking to expand her real estate practice.

I've lived here for just about 2 years now, and began to get settled into a routine just before I lost my job.  I began to feel comfortable here, and began to give up my dream of living in the city, being a part of a dynamic, welcoming, church community, and having a job that made me feel like I was truly living up to my potential - both career-wise and spiritually/emotionally.  I think that's why I see my loss of job as a blessing not a curse.  I was going to get stuck in this little bitty mountain town.  So, I looked for jobs here but couldn't find one (demand isn't real high for youth professionals here).  And my heart kept pulling me towards Atlanta.  It's a city, I have a large group of friends there already thanks to church activities that I've been a part of since high school, and it's close to my family.  It's perfect.  I get a job, a church, a circle of friends (new and old), and a city, all without having to make a huge move to another state. 

Thanks for playing ... I'm up for follow-up questions if you have any. :)

I tried this a week or so ago and got no response, so I thought I'd try it again and see if I get any takers this time around

Everyone has things they blog about. Everyone has things they don't blog about. Challenge me out of my comfort zone by telling me something I don't blog about, but you'd like to hear about, and I'll (maybe) write a post about it.

Ask for anything: latest movie watched, last book read, political leanings, thoughts on religion, favorite type of underwear, etc.

Repost in your own journal so that we can all learn more about each othe!

So it's supposed to rain all week...how in the heck am I gonna move three mattresses (a twin mattress and box spring, and a futon mattress) in the back of a truck from Blairsville to Atlanta if it's gonna rain all frickin' week?  Annoying.  I'm so ready to be in Atlanta that I'm going crazy ... although I guess I could use the extra time to get things together.  My plan is to take a car load down tomorrow and clean the place, and then hopefully Wednesday will be clear enough to move the rest of the stuff down.

I got to go tanning today - I know all the studies about how bad UV rays are and my brain totally tells me I shouldn't go to the tanning bed, but I tell you what ... the time I lay in that bed is amazing.  It's total me time.  10-20 minutes of complete ME.  Amazing.

Not much else going on - packing, packing, and more packing.  It's been a while since my last book review - I've got two on the back burner waiting to be finished.  The Bible: A Biography by Karen Armstrong, and I just got Centering Prayer: Renewing an Ancient Christian Prayer Form by Basil Pennington from the library today.  I'm looking forward to both of them.  I'll have some time without tv (not getting cable for a month at least) so hopefully I'll get to finish one, or both, in the next couple of weeks.  Fun books this week include Janet Evanovich's Lean Mean Thirteen (plan to be done with that one tonight) and The Other Boleyn Girl by Philippa Gregory for April's book club book.  I had forgotten how much I love to read :)

Off to evaluate what is left on my checklist to pack :)

Home after a wonderful weekend with some amazing youth from the Southeastern Synod (for those of you non-ELCA Lutheran people, that's Alabama, Mississippi, Tennessee, and Georgia).  Reminded me that God has definitely blessed me with gifts and skills to work with youth in the church.  I promise to go through all posts from Friday on and leave comments as I feel inspired :)

A real update soon ... probably tomorrow sometime.

Signed my lease today and got my keys for my new Atlanta apartment.  Zip Code 30305.  I love it.  Michelle and I ate outside at Moe's (Welcome to Moe's!) while watching traffic and buses go by, had dessert at the Cheesecake Factory, went to Ikea, found our way around back roads to Atlantic Station, tried to figure out the best way for me to get to work (we think Piedmont is the better choice than Peachtree), and ooohed and awwwed at the mcmansions on West Paces Ferry Road (not in any particular order).  Atlanta is so completely where I belong.  I already have a social group (or two) and am already a member (or almost member) of a book club!

After all that, I'm exhausted.  Having breakfast with a friend of mine from my old job in the morning, so I'm excited about that.  Then, I get my haircut (so desperately needed) and head to Dickson TN for the SESLYO Assembly.  It's gonna be a tiring weekend, but so totally worth it.  Monday I'll pack up all my stuff and Tuesday I'll move in.  By Thursday I should be a full-fledged Atlantan.  I think I'll even send myself a piece of mail so I can get a library card at the Atlanta library on Wednesday or Thursday :)

You probably won't hear from me over the next few days - I'll be without internet.  I should try to figure out how to do mobile posting, but not today - my brain is too tired.

I am currently taking donations for a new phone - I'd really like a blackberry (or other similar type) so that I don't have to pay for internet at my new apartment.  Anyone who wants to contribute, please feel free to send any donations my way :)  

Enough randomness for one night.  Sweet dreams my loves.

Everyone has things they blog about. Everyone has things they don't blog about. Challenge me out of my comfort zone by telling me something I don't blog about, but you'd like to hear about, and I'll (maybe) write a post about it.

Ask for anything: latest movie watched, last book read, political leanings, thoughts on religion, favorite type of underwear, etc.

Repost in your own journal so that we can all learn more about each other!

Have any of you ever read The Abstinence Teacher by Tom Perrotta?  I had never heard of it until I was at the library one day glancing at the New Release shelf and there it was, staring at me.  Some of you may know the work I have done against abstinence-only education programs, so I was naturally intrigued by the title.  (Side note - I'm happy to discuss the topic at any time if any of you are interested).  The book tells the story of two main characters living in suburbia america - one is a sex ed teacher who thinks Christianity is pointless and the other is a born-again Christian, who has been saved from his drug and alcohol addictions by his belief in Christ.  This born-again Christian is a member of a large fundamentalist Christian church, which is pushing abstinence education, prayer in schools and public places, etc.  I have mixed feelings about this book.  On the one hand, Perrotta explores the struggle between the two viewpoints quite well, using quite a bit of humor and sarcasm.  On the other hand, the book is very stereotypical.  After reading some of the reviews of the book on Amazon, I'm beginning to think the stereotypes are his way of using satire to express the ridiculousness of both extremes and the need to meet in the middle; however, I didn't think that satire was extremely clear throughout the book. 

If you have read it, I'd be interested in your thoughts.

1. Did you vote in your most recent applicable election? (If you're not yet old enough, do you plan to vote in the future?)
I most certainly did :)

2. Have you ever protested or attended a march?
Yes - it is quite a moving experience

3. What political issue is the most important to you?
I don't know if there's one single issue that is the most important to me - the broadest issue is bridging the gap between the rich and the poor, which seems to only be getting bigger.  There are so many political issues tied into that though.

4. Are you a member of a party in your country? If so, which?
I am technically a member of the Democratic party; however, I have been known to vote for Republicans if I like their policies and their personalities.

5. Do you ever plan to run for office?
I can't say that I PLAN to run for office, but I can definitely see myself getting active in the political arena - and I guess the possibility is there ... maybe one day.
I got my new glasses today ... and I.LOVE.THEM!!  They are super awesome and look great, if I do say so myself :)

I actually finished this book (and began the review) on Friday, but I wanted to wait to post it after I posted details about my job, so now that you know about the job, here goes the review :)  When I first interviewed with Redeemer, I put this book on my list of "to read" books.  Pastor Foss gave me a copy when I went down the second time, and I am so grateful to have had a chance to read it.  Because there is so much in this book I wanted to talk about, I've broken the book review up into sections. 

Membership vs. Discipleship
Foss discusses that in a membership driven congregation, the focus is what the members of the congregation want/need/etc.  In a discipleship driven congregation, the focus is on what God is calling us to do (or not to do).  We can't be aware of what God is calling us to unless we become disciples.  The focus is on spiritual development of the people in the congregation.  Not necessarily on making them happy, but on encouraging, and expecting, them to grow in their faith by practicing the six marks of discipleship.

What are the Six Marks of Discipleship?
Power Surge is named after the six marks of discipleship.  Pray daily, Worship weekly, Read the Bible daily, Serve, both inside and outside a congregation, being a part of Relationships and Christian community, and Giving (tithing).  Foss believes that if a church, and members of that church (or disciples in that church) practice these six marks of discipleship, the congregation will experience a power surge.

Personal Thoughts and Reflection
I related to a lot of what was written in this book.  What I didn't realize while I was at First Lutheran in Ohio, but I realized as I was reading, is that the "corporate" model First was using as a leadership model is the same model that Foss uses and describes as a discipleship model.  It makes so much more sense to me being grounded in the marks of discipleship rather than thinking of the church as being "corporate".  I also realized that the mission developers here in Blairsville are also using some parts of this discipleship model; although it's never been introduced as such.

The discipleship model that he speaks of makes so much sense to me.  To me, my faith is all about my relationship with God.  My relationship with God cannot grow or expand its depth unless I'm reading the Bible, spending time in prayer, etc.  Before my time of unemployment, I had a relationship with God, and I thought about God often, but my personal relationship with God had been more distant than I would have liked.  Vocare showed me the importance of community in my spiritual growth and my relationship with God - I can better understand my relationship with God if I have relationships with other people who show me pictures of God in their words and actions.  I have always understood the connection between serving and my relationship with God, and I'm pretty good at the worship part.  Even though we haven't been part of a congregation while we were here in Blairsville, I always tried to take time to worship God through music and conversation (which I guess is prayer).  The giving part is the hardest for me - when you live paycheck to paycheck like we do, it requires a lot of faith to give up 10% of what you're getting.  I'm trying to remember that what I get is not mine in the first place, and if I give it back to God, then God will take care of making sure I have what I need.  It requires smarter choices, and less consumerism.  These are good things to learn, but to me, the hardest.

Although I got a lot out of this book as an individual, it seems to be best read in the context of a congregational (or small group) study.  There are some great reflection questions included at the end of each chapter, which I'm sure would spark some very interesting discussion among group members.  If any of you have read this book and/or have participated in a study group of this book, I'd love to hear your thoughts and reviews :)

1. What do you see when you are looking out of the window closest to you? My front porch - and a dreary day outside
  2. Who was the last person coming into your room? Do the kitties count?  If not, me, since I'm home alone.  And before that, Josh.   We haven't had visitors in a while
  3. What is the most predominant colour around you? Brown, in different shades
  4. What is right behind you? the awesome kitty quilt my Aunt Jay made me for Christmas
  5. What is on today's calendar sheet? Finish laundry, pack, head to Rome for the weekend to visit Michelle, email my Young Harris Lutheran Campus Ministry peeps, finish Power Surge so I can post a book review, post said book review - WOW i better get busy!

I went to the eye doctor today for my annual checkup.  They dialated my eyes - I hate that.  It's 75 degrees outside, full of sunshine, and I'm stuck inside in the dark for the afternoon because the sun makes my dialated eyes and head hurt.  BOO HISS.  I wanted to go enjoy the beautiful weather - run, read outside, etc...but I'll have to pass.  Maybe tomorrow will be just as pretty, although they are calling for lots of rain.  On the up side, I got new glasses :)  THEY ARE PINK!!  They are Cynthia Rowley (Jenn Lake will be proud) and this is what they look like:



They should be back in about a week - yay! 

You'll have to wait until Monday for details on my new job.  They were supposed to email me the details today, but one of the people has a sick child and won't be back in until Monday, so my patience hat has to stay on a little bit longer.  I have; however, been told to "rest assured, it is on its way."  I promise when I have the details I will share :)

Thanks for all of your thoughts and prayers through this time.  Many of you know what a challenging time it's been.  What some of you might not know is what a growing experience it has been.  I'm so glad to have had the downtime that I had to really stay focused on God and how God is active in my life.  It's sort of ironic that the beginning of it all fell so very close to Ash Wednesday - I truly have had a remarkable Lenten journey.  This Easter will certainly be a celebration!

gakked from
mama_bec


1. Did you date someone from your school?
oh yeah ... several someones :)

2. Did you win anything in Seniors Who's Who?
no - sadly i moved my senior year so no one really knew me

my first car (which lasted 6 months) was an '83 Dodge Challenger.  I then got a '93 Chevy Cavalier which I drove until it died.  I miss that car.

4. It's Friday night...where are you?
during fall, I was with the marching band at football games.  during spring, i was "cruisin' town"

nope

6. Were you considered a flirt?
by some :)

7. Were you in band, orchestra, or choir?
band all the way through - I was in chorus when we moved because i needed an extra class.

8. Were you a nerd?
a cool nerd - like Rory Gilmore :)

9. Did you get suspended/expelled?
nope

nope

11. Who were your favorite teachers?

<lj-template name="qotd" id="325"></lj-template>I love this question.  My two sisters totally affect who I am as a person.  I don't think I have one memory from childhood that doesn't have them in it.  Sure we had our fights growing up, but they both are two of my very best friends.  They are younger, but boy have they taught me a lot - how to listen, how to be a leader, how to give advice (or not give advice, depending on the situation), how to ward off a hangover, how to put on eye makeup, how to pick out clothes, and so much more.  Having a sibling means ALWAYS having someone to call to cry on, to laugh with, to take a random road trip with, to go to dinner with, to pick up food for you when you feel like poop-on-a-stick, to share your joys and fears with, to talk about boys with, etc. etc. etc.  It also means there's always someone there to tell you how great you are when you're having bad days, or to put you in your place when you think you're the shit.  They have taught me to stand up for what I believe in, to not be afraid of taking risks, and to be proud of who I am.  They've taught me that to be different from one another is a blessing.  They've also taught me that if I ever do have kids, they will be there to be the most awesome aunts in the world (next to our aunts of course!)

As a true southern girl who loves sweet tea, this website makes me giggle :)  I mean, come on - seriously?  HOW TO make tea?

In other news, Josh's interview went well today.  And I received a call for a final interview Monday at my perspective place of employment.  Things are looking good for our upcoming move to Atlanta.  Now if we can only find a buyer for our beautiful, wonderful, gorgeous house that we don't want to have to sell.  Too bad we couldn't just pick it up and move it downtown somewhere.

Started reading a new book today - Power Surge: The Six Marks of Discipleship by Michael Foss.  So far, it's v. good.  Promise to review it when I'm done :)

I started reading this book as part of a Lenten study group at the local Episcopal church.  When we went to the church for Ash Wednesday service, I noticed they were reading it as their Lenten study and I instantly felt that it was something I needed to read during my time of discernment.  I told Josh last night that this book has completely changed my life.  It truly is transformative - as long as you read it with an open mind and an open heart, and are willing to be completely honest with yourself.  She challenged me in a way I have not been challenged before.  And I have to be completely honest - there are things I discovered about myself that I didn't like. 

The book is broken up into four parts: 1) Letting Go - Why? 2) Letting Go - Of What? 3) Letting Go - How? and 4) Am I on the Right Track?

The why seems really simple, but she doesn't write only about why we should let go, but more importantly, why are we stuck in the first place?  I think it was this first part that affected me the most.  So often we don't even realize that we ARE stuck, or that there is anything that we need to let go of.  Or, if we do realize we are stuck, we are so afraid of taking a risk to something different, and maybe even unknown, that we are paralyzed by our fear. 

In the what section, she uses tons and tons of examples of things that we hold on to and breaks them up into five sections (I call them the 5 P's): people, personas, perspectives, patterns, and plans.  There is most definitely something for everyone.  I identified several examples in each section that I hold on to in one form or another.  One of the most powerful to me is the need to let go of the perspective "I Must Be Sure."  So often I hesitate in making a decision because I'm afraid that it's the wrong decision.  I hold on to the idea that I have to be 100% sure that God is calling me to do that thing before I want to commit to it.  Douty says "God's guidance usually evolves one step at a time.  Rather than wait for the entire agenda to be laid before us, we're called simply to take the next step."  So I'm working on taking the next step, and trusting that God's light will lead me along the steps I am called to make.

She divides the how section into five steps: Awareness, Availability, Action, Allowance, and Acceptance.  We first have to become aware of the fact that we need to let go, and also of what we need to let go.  Most often, this awareness comes from self-reflection and silent meditation.  We then have to be available to the process of letting go - we have to DO that what we KNOW we need to do.  So, we move towards action ... taking part in some activity that will help us let go.  The hardest part for me is the allowance and acceptance part.  We have to allow the process to work - it doesn't happen overnight, it takes time.  She uses a garden metaphor.  After you've done all the work in planting flowers, you have to step back, nurture it, and allow the growth to happen.  The nurturing part is hardest when you can't see immediate results. 

It's a wonderfully fabulous book.  I've recommended it to several people as I've been reading along the way.  Linda Douty gets five stars from me.  For challenging me, for inspiring me, for transforming me, for calling me out, and for being a glimpse of God to me through her words.

I've been using the Moravian Daily Texts, as published by Mount Carmel Ministries, in my daily prayer life.  Today's New Testament reading  was 1 Corinthians 13:5.  I've never read any part of 1 Corinthians 13 without all the rest of it.  This simple statement was incredibly powerful to me today.  "Love is not rude.  It does not insist on its own way."  After reading it, I thought - wow, that's profound.  And then I thought about it a little more.  We typically read this chapter as "the love chapter" - it's read at weddings all the time.  How appropriate we say!  That's what God has in mind for the perfect marriage - and whenever we're struggling, we can read it and remind ourselves of just how much work love is ... and what love actually means.  But here's the thing - not only does God love us, but God is Love.  So if God is Love, then the verse really reads: God is not rude.  God does not insist on God's own way.  Introduce the concept of free well.  God has given us free will because God is Love - and Love does not insist on its own way.  Love allows the other to make choices, even when they may hurt us or someone else.  Love may not agree with our choice, but Love sticks with us despite the choice.  And if we fall because of the choice we make, Love is right there to pick us back up.  My Mom has this whole Love thing down - she has always allowed us to make our own decisions, from the time we were old enough to understand what a decision was.  She always helped us see both sides, but then allowed us to "do it our way".  She never left our side though - I know there are countless decisions I made that she didn't agree with, but she always supported my decision.  And then, when I fell, she was there to hug me, to pick me back up, and to say "that's okay - now you can make a different decision."  I wonder if she knows how much she has shaped my understanding of God - I guess I need to share that with her one day soon :)

I came across this book when I was a serving on the Churchwide Program Committee for the Church in Society Unit.  I have been intrigued by the concept of simplicity since college, when I wrote a paper on Simple Living for one of my classes.  When writing my paper, I focused primarily on the Amish and Quaker tradition - one book I read was called "A Plain Life: Walking My Beliefs".  The author walked a 120 miles across Ohio to turn in his driver's license, and he joined a Quaker community.  I was intrigued by my research, and thought I could for certain pare down the life I lived, but was never completely comfortable with the thought of "a plain life".  I've had this book on my shelf for over a year now, with every intention of reading it - but never found the time.  The day I returned from Vocare, I decided that I was going to make my time of unemployment, regardless of how long or short it was, a time of discernment and sabbatical.  So I went to my library upstairs and glanced at the books - this one basically screamed at me to take it off the shelf and open it.  I'm glad I did. 

The book is written in journal format - so we experience her own journey with discovering what it means to live simply.  In her introduction, she poses the question "What is necessary?" and returns to this thought throughout the book.  I was impressed by how balanced her simple life is.  No, she doesn't own a car - but she doesn't mind to borrow or rent one when she needs one for long trips or chores that require the use of a vehicle.  She doesn't own a TV, or an ipod, but she did get a cell phone for use at work.  She does own a washer and a dryer - although she tries to hang dry her clothes as much as possible.  I love her illustration of the difference in frugality and simple living.  Frugality is not wanting to spend money, period.  Simple living is about so much more than that.  Simple living is about living a lifestyle that illustrates God's culture.  Think what the world would be like if we asked ourselves before every purchase "Is this something that lifts up the name of God?"  She values experience over items - after all, experiences are what shape us through our lives.  We will take our experiences with us.  The things will be left here for someone else to deal with.

What I learned while reading this book is how simplicity is choice we have to make daily, and sometimes hourly.   I can get Starbucks and live a simple life - if I make it a special treat, or if I use "Starbucks time" as a time to build community with others.  But simply buying a latte just because I'm driving by a Starbucks and it sounds good, is more consumerish than God-culturish.  This book is one that I want to put on my list to read at the start of every season - to remind myself of what living simply means, and to measure how far (or not) I've come in sustaining simplicity in my own life.  It holds very important lessons for us, especially as we struggle financially and prepare for a move to a very consumer-driven city. 

I highly recommend this book to anyone and everyone.  If you're interested and want to purchase your own copy, check out Augsburg Fortress - it's not yet available at Amazon.

According to livejournal, it's been 35 weeks since I last posted.  WOOPS!  So here I am, posting ... and making a promise to you (whoever may be reading this) that I will do my best to update regularly.  I would like for this to be my brainstorming place - so I'll try to be better.

A lot has happened in 35 weeks.  Probably the most significant is that I lost my job at the end of January.  Since then, I've done a lot of soul searching, praying, listening, reading, and discerning what God is calling me to.  I'm reading several books at the moment, all of which have been incredibly wonderful at helping me to be honest with myself about where I am in my personal and spiritual life.  I think I'll do a book review of each of them when I finish them, as a way of reflecting on the book and how it affected me.  Plus - one more way to update right? :)

The day after I lost my job, I attended an Episcopal Young Adult Gathering called "Vocare".  Although I was frustrated during the weekend for several reasons, I have to say that it was a transformative weekend for me.  I think a lot of it was timing - because I had just lost my job, I was completely open to what God was saying to me.  We had a lot of time during the weekend for silence, and I never realized how comforting complete silence can be when you use it to focus on God.  Something else I learned from Vocare was the real value of prayer.  I have never been one to sit and pray at any specific time - I usually pray by just randomly talking to God.  We were given an Anglican Rosary (also known as Anglican Prayer Beads) and I was also given the opportunity to make one to be sold as a fundraiser for the Atlanta area Episcopal Young Adult group.  The prayer beads have been an incredible addition to my prayer life - as one whose mind wanders when I try to focus on prayer, it is helpful to have something solid to focus on when saying prayers.  The most important thing I learned from Vocare is that I NEED a Christian community.  Many of you know that we have been without a church since we moved to GA - we have visited a couple of churches, but never found a place where we truly felt comfortable.  We decided to visit the local Episcopal church for Ash Wednesday service, and instantly felt the presence of God.  The people were so welcoming, and the service was very centering.  I've been participating in their Lenten Evening Prayer services and Lenten study, and it has been a great experience to be a part of a Christian community again.  

We are anticipating a move to Atlanta very soon.  When I have firm details, I will post more - it will probably be next week sometime.  We have listed the house on craigslist, owners.com and Josh's work intranet.  We've had a couple people interested so far, so we're trusting that God will take care of everything in the right time frame.  We are learning a lot about surrendering to God's will and trusting that God will supply everything that we need.

Those are the highlights of our life as of right now.  Look for a book review tomorrow or Sunday and a "move update" sometime soon!

Updates in bullet form:

* Went to AFFIRM last week at University of Northern Alabama in Florence, AL.  It was awesome!  Can't wait til AFFIRM 2008 :)

* Got two new kittens.  Actually, I'm only keeping one - Michelle is taking the other.  They are adorable ... both orange and only weigh 1 pound 4 ounces each.  We're naming them Sugar and Spice.  

* I'm dog sitting starting Thursday until mid-July.  Yup - we will be living in a zoo ... and loving every bit of it.

* Michelle and I got matching cross tattoos today.  We'll post some pictures on Facebook sometime this evening - so check them out.  We saved a turtle's life on the way home ... it felt good.

* Happy Birthday to Michelle today - she's 19.

* Only 23 days til Josh and I get to go to Kiawah Island Golf Resort!

* Back to work tomorrow ... my boss is there for 3 days and then I'm running the show for 10 days without her.  Say some prayers :)

Last night I read this article in the new Self Recipe magazine about a woman who thrives on cooking healthy meals - cooking is her outlet when she's bored, mad, angry, upset, sad, etc.  As I was reading it, I realized just how much I identify with that.  When I come home from a long day, the last thing I want to do is cook - right?  Nope ... actually, most times I think I don't want to cook but once I get going I absolutely love it.  It almost feels like an accomplishment of sorts - take all these little bitty pieces and put it together into one delicious, and healthy, meal.  I can make what seems like a meal from a 5-star restaurant in 30-45 minutes and it's way less caloric!  One of the things I learned over the last 16 months is that eating healthy doesn't have to be boring - and in fact, eating healthy can be more exciting than eating stuff that society tells us "tastes so good."  I had McDonalds last week for the first time in about a year, and I can't believe I used to think McDonalds was good.  I seriously thought I was gonna puke after eating it.  I feel the same way about Taco Bell, Burger King, Wendy's, and just about every other fast food restaurant out there.  It sorta sickens me that I used to eat it and like it!

Anyhow - tonight I made Glazed Pork Chops and Apples, with AuGratin potatoes, and Carrot Slaw (just hollar if you want any recipes).  The pork chops and apples are finishing up on the grill right now.  Popped open a bottle of wine and am letting it air out - got the table set, and I'm ready for my 5-star meal.  Now if only I had the restaurant crew to clean up after me 
;-)

Just a quick post to let you know ...

I passed the GA Bar Exam :-)

I know I know, I've heard it from everyone - "Big surprise - we knew you did" but - you just never ever know until you finally get the results.  My result letter came today.  It'll probably be a month or so before I can actually practice in GA - there's a lot left to do ... but it's good to know I can take the next steps.

YIPPEE!

Okay, maybe not JUST in - but still relatively new news ... my sister (April, the middle sister) got married.  Yup, randomly - they went to the courthouse two weeks ago on Monday and came out married.  I'm excited for her - they are both super happy.  AND - they're buying a house ... they close on Tuesday.  It's actually the first house that Josh and I fell in love with, put an offer on, and then decided we didn't like the seller's attitude.  I'm so excited for them - because they ended up buying it for $20K less than our final offer on it - so TAKE THAT BUTTHEAD SELLER!  So anyway, it's been an exciting couple of weeks for them, and now we're planning a drop-in reception for them (sort of like a wedding shower, only after the wedding!)  It'll be the Saturday of Memorial Day weekend - if you're interested, or want an invite, let me know and I'll add you to the list.

Not much other news in our lives here.  I am absolutely loving my job and I learn a ton every single day.  I'm doing mostly estate administration work right now, with some real estate mixed in.  I really enjoy the estate administration work, but we see some really sad stories and some disgruntled families.  It's so sad how that happens - I hope that whenever my parents die (which I hope is a hundred years from now) me and my sisters can work through it without being jealous of one another.

One other thing - I'm having a Pampered Chef party on May 3 at 6:30pm.  I'm excited to host my first party at my new house.  I've always liked being a host, but never really had the group of friends to invite over for any particular reason, so this should be fun.  If you've ever wanted to order Pampered Chef stuff but never had a contact, send your order in to me and I'll make sure you get it :)

Off to enjoy my day off ... I love Fridays :)

Monday was magical because... I kicked myself back into gear on a healthy track - I walked 2.5 miles, then came home to pull all the weeds out of my garden ... a total of about 2 straight hours of good exercise - yay me!

Tuesday, what a tiring day, because... tuesday is just a blah day - it's the middle of the week, but closer to the beginning, so it drags ... and this tuesday we had super bad storms and lost our power and our phone was struck by lightening ... man - exhausting!

My Wednesday was wild & crazy because... staff meeting, stacks of stuff to get done, and tons of walk-ins who just had to see me

Thursday made me think about... how much I truly appreciate our support staff at work.  When one or more of them is out, work is hectic and way super crazy.

Friday is the most fun because of... my day off every single week.  Oh how I love it!

The bar exam is over and I am back to work in full swing.  We had a crazy week last week - it felt really good to be able to devote myself 100% to it and not have that dumb exam hanging over my head.  I am officially a full time working girl, and I like it :-)

Last Saturday, as part of my "Exam is over, let's get back on track" I signed up for the Self challenge.  I really need to get back into the habit of taking care of myself by eating well and exercising.  I did an okay job this week ... I could have done better, but that's okay - today starts a new week and I'll do better.  I WILL be bikini-ready by June - even though I won't be going anywhere to wear a bikini this year.  Any of you interested in signing up for the Self Challenge with me?  Check it out here.

Yesterday was my first Friday off with no studying to do.  So I spent it doing random stuff around the house.  I paid all my bills for the rest of the month and then installed Quicken on our computer and set up our checkbook and budget.  If you don't have Quicken, it is a good purchase.  That program can do all sorts of things.  With us buying our house, we had to really sit down and figure out where our money was going and where it had to go, so we created a preliminary budget to get us through February, when I could sit down and put it on the computer.  I put it all in Quicken yesterday and I really think it'll help us stick to it.  It means I have to plan my shopping sprees instead of just going, but I have faith that I can do it :-)  Josh gets to go bowling every week, so I'm gonna try to put my "play" money into a box somewhere and save it for clothes, shoes, mani-pedis, etc. etc. etc.  UGH - I am officially now a real live adult ... and I don't know if I like it yet or not.

We're all moved in - only a few boxes (mostly summer clothes) left to go through and find a place for.  We have lots of spare room - two extra twin beds and a futon that is actually pretty comfortable, plus lots of extra floor space - so if you're passing through the north GA mountains and need a place to crash for the night, feel free to "stop on by" ;-)  I'll try to post some pictures soon.

Better get myself going for the day.  Have a good weekend!!

1. If you could retroactively erase one TV show from the history of entertainment, which one would you choose?
ESPN - the entire channel

2. Are you more like your mother or your father?
That's a no brainer - definitely my mother.  Unless my stepdad counts - I think I may be more like him in many ways.

3. If you could take a year-long vacation, what would you do?
Travel all over Sub-Saharan Africa, India, and other places of extreme poverty so I could gain some perspective on just on rich I really am - even though I don't feel it very often.

4. Can you think of a reason not to answer this question?


5. What's the nicest thing you've ever done for someone?
I try to do nice things for people all the time.  I don't know what the nicest thing is I've ever done ... I guess you'd have to ask my friends and family that.

1. What do you like most: Fridays, Saturdays, or Sundays (and why)?
Definitely Fridays.  I'm off on Fridays and it can be super productive because the rest of the world has to work!

2. What was the best weekend of your life?
The weekend of my wedding ... Josh and I drove from the wedding to DisneyWorld and had the best time!

3. What weekend of the year is your favorite?
Easter weekend.  There's so much history with it, and it's spring time, and beautiful, and a great time to remember what I believe in.

4. Do you have any weekend routines?
Grocery shopping generally happens on the weekend, other than that - we just go with whatever is planned for the weekend ... it's usually different every weekend.

5. Describe your ideal Saturday night.
I don't really have an ideal Saturday night.  I like variety - sometimes staying home is ideal, sometimes heading out to a play or movie or a girls night out is ideal.

I am officially done with my studying and exam taking (well, assuming I pass the GA Bar Exam)!  I finished the test today around 4:30pm and can now go on with my life of working and playing and NO STUDYING!  I can't wait to make the quilts I have stacked up, to read the books I have shelved (and boxed), to decorate and organize my new house, and oh I can think of a thousand other things that I will now be able to do now that the stupid bar exam is finally behind me.  I'm staying in Atlanta tonight because the drive home would take me about 4 hours if I left now (thanks to good ole' ATL rush hour) so I'll head home tomorrow when it'll take me 2 instead.  I'm trying to decide what I want to do tonight ... I may go do some shopping, buy some coffee from the local Barnes & Noble (since I can't seem to find a Starbucks or Caribou), watch American Idol and any other brainless TV I can find on that looks even remotely entertaining.


Happy Trails!

1. Would you rather serve in heaven or rule in hell?

Serve in heaven

2. If you had evidence that would catch a killer, but also put you in jail, would you use it?

It depends on what it would put me in jail for ... I bet I could work a deal where I could catch the killer and not be put in jail.  I'm sure I could find a good attorney to represent me.

3. If you could work the worst job you have ever had, for three years and then never have to work again, would you or would you rather work the job you always wanted but not be able to retire until well past the age of retirement?

I'd rather work the job I always wanted but not be able to retire.  My worst job was really really bad - I wouldn't want to do it for 3 years.

4. If you could write four newspaper headlines, which would come true, what would they be?

Doctors Find a Cure for HIV/AIDS

ELCA Changes Policy on Homosexuality

No More War

Fair Trade Mandated

George Bush Impeached

5. A video of children in Florida fighting, while adults cheer on, was posted on the popular web site MySpace, The popularity of "gang videos" has also increased, and there has been renewed interest in re creating the infamous "Faces of Death" video series, do you feel there should be laws limiting extreme videos?

Yes, if the definition of "extreme videos" can be incredibly  limited.  If too broad, it becomes a precedent for a slippery slope towards limiting all types of speech - which is directly contrary to our Constitution.  No matter how much those videos may disgust me, I have a choice to not watch them.  I'd rather have a choice to not watch them than be told I can't watch them.  Instead, we should focus on educating people as to why those videos are "bad" rather than making them "illegal."  History shows when you ban something, it becomes more popular.
